children.title: Quick Start
children.description: Starting fresh? Getting started with Nuxt 3 is straightforward!

children.title: Migration Guide
children.description: Already have a Nuxt project to migrate? These migration guides are for users wanting to upgrade their Nuxt application to Nuxt 3 or take the first step in that direction with Nuxt Bridge.

children.title: What is Nuxt?
children.description: Nuxt's goal is to make web development intuitive and performant with a great developer experience in mind.

children.title: Vue.js Development
children.description: Nuxt uses Vue as a frontend framework and adds features such as component auto-imports and file-based routing. Nuxt 3 integrates Vue 3, the new major release of Vue that enables new patterns for Nuxt users.

children.title: Rendering Modes
children.description: Both the browser and server can interpret JavaScript code to render Vue.js components into HTML elements. This step is called rendering. Nuxt supports both client-side and universal rendering. The two approaches have pros and cons that we will cover in this section.

children.title: Auto Imports
children.description: Nuxt auto-imports helper functions, composables and Vue APIs to use across your application without explicitly importing them. Based on the directory structure, every Nuxt application can also use auto-imports for its own components, composables and plugins. Components, composables or plugins can use these functions.

children.title: Server Engine
children.description: Nuxt 3 is powered by a new server engine, code-named "Nitro".

children.title: TypeScript
children.description: Nuxt 3 is fully typed and provides helpful shortcuts to ensure you have access to accurate type information when you are coding.

children.title: Assets
children.description: Nuxt uses two directories to handle assets like stylesheets, fonts or images:

children.title: Head Management
children.description: Out-of-the-box, Nuxt provides good default values for charset and viewport meta tags, but you can override these if you need to, as well as customize other meta tags for your site in several different ways.

children.title: Data Fetching
children.description: Nuxt provides useFetch, useLazyFetch, useAsyncData and useLazyAsyncData to handle data fetching within your application.

children.title: State Management
children.description: Nuxt provides useState composable to create a reactive and SSR-friendly shared state across components.

children.title: Server Routes
children.description: Nuxt automatically scans files inside the ~/server/api, ~/server/routes, and ~/server/middleware directories to register API and server handlers with HMR support.

children.title: Runtime Config
children.description: Nuxt provides a runtime config API to expose config within your application and server routes with the ability to update them at runtime using environment variables.

children.title: Teleports
children.description: Vue 3 provides the <Teleport> component which allows content to be rendered elsewhere in the DOM, outside of the Vue application.

children.title: Modules
children.description: Nuxt provides a module system to extend the framework core and simplify integrations. You don't need to develop everything from scratch or maintain boilerplate if there is already a Nuxt module for it. Adding Nuxt modules is possible using nuxt.config.

children.title: .nuxt
children.description: Nuxt uses the .nuxt/ directory in development to generate your Vue application.

children.title: .output
children.description: Nuxt creates the .output/ directory when building your application for production.

children.title: assets
children.description: The assets/ directory is used to add all the website's assets that the build tool (webpack or Vite) will process.

children.title: components
children.description: The components/ directory is where you put all your Vue components which can then be imported inside your pages or other components (learn more).

children.title: composables
children.description: Nuxt 3 supports composables/ directory to automatically import your Vue composables into your application using auto-imports!

children.title: content
children.description: The Nuxt Content module reads the content/ directory in your project and parses .md, .yml, .csv and .json files to create a file-based CMS for your application.

children.title: layouts
children.description: Nuxt provides a customizable layouts framework you can use throughout your application, ideal for extracting common UI or code patterns into reusable layout components.

children.title: middleware
children.description: Nuxt provides a customizable route middleware framework you can use throughout your application, ideal for extracting code that you want to run before navigating to a particular route.

children.title: node_modules
children.description: The package manager (npm or yarn or pnpm) creates the node_modules directory to store the dependencies of your project.

children.title: pages
children.description: Nuxt provides a file-based routing to create routes within your web application using Vue Router under the hood.

children.title: plugins
children.description: Nuxt will automatically read the files in your plugins directory and load them. You can use .server or .client suffix in the file name to load a plugin only on the server or client side.

children.title: public
children.description: The public/ directory is directly served at the server root and contains public files that have to keep their names (e.g. robots.txt) or likely won't change (e.g. favicon.ico).

children.title: .gitignore
children.description: A .gitignore file specifies intentionally untracked files that git should ignore. Learn more about it in the git documentation.

children.title: app.vue
children.description: The app.vue file is the main component in your Nuxt 3 applications.

children.title: .nuxtignore
children.description: You can use a .nuxtignore file to let Nuxt ignore layout, pages, components, composables and middleware files in your project’s root directory (rootDir) during the build phase. The .nuxtignore file is subject to the same specification as .gitignore and .eslintignore files, in which each line is a glob pattern indicating which files should be ignored.

children.title: nuxt.config.ts
children.description: Nuxt can be easily configured with a single nuxt.config file, which can have either a .js, .ts or .mjs extension.

children.title: package.json
children.description: The package.json file contains all the dependencies and scripts for your application (learn more).

children.title: tsconfig.json
children.description: Nuxt automatically generates a .nuxt/tsconfig.json file with the resolved aliases you are using in your Nuxt project, as well as with other sensible defaults. You can benefit from this by creating a tsconfig.json in the root of your project with the following content:

children.title: Node.js Server
children.description: Discover the Node.js server preset with Nitro to deploy on any Node hosting.

children.title: Deployment Presets
children.description: In addition to Node.js servers and static hosting services, a Nuxt 3 project can be deployed with several well-tested presets and minimal amount of configuration.

children.title: AWS
children.description: How to deploy Nuxt to AWS Lambda

children.title: Azure
children.description: How to deploy to Azure Static Web Apps or Azure Functions.

children.title: Cloudflare Workers
children.description: How to deploy Nuxt to Cloudflare Workers.

children.title: DigitalOcean
children.description: Nitro supports deploying on the Digital Ocean App Platform with minimal configuration.

children.title: Firebase Hosting
children.description: How to deploy Nuxt to Firebase Hosting.

children.title: Heroku
children.description: How to deploy Nuxt to Heroku.

children.title: Layer0
children.description: Nitro provides a built-in preset to generate output format compatible with Layer0.

children.title: Netlify
children.description: How to deploy Nuxt to Netlify.

children.title: Render
children.description: How to deploy Nuxt to Render

children.title: StormKit
children.description: How to deploy Nuxt to StormKit.

children.title: Vercel
children.description: Nuxt on Vercel supports server-rendered pages and API routes.

children.title: How Nuxt Works?
children.description: Nuxt is a minimal but highly customizable framework to build web applications. This guide helps you better understand Nuxt internals to develop new solutions and module integrations on top of Nuxt.

children.title: Lifecycle Hooks
children.description: Nuxt provides a powerful hooking system to expand almost every aspect using hooks powered by unjs/hookable.

children.title: Module Author Guide
children.description:
Nuxt provides a zero-config experience with a preset of integrations and best practices to develop Web applications.
A powerful configuration and hooks system makes it possible to customize almost every aspect of Nuxt Framework and add endless possible integrations when it comes to customization. You can learn more about how nuxt works in the Nuxt internals section.

children.title: ES Modules
children.description: Nuxt 3 (and Bridge) uses Native ES Modules.

children.title: NuxtApp
children.description: In Nuxt 3, you can access runtime app context within composables, components and plugins.

children.title: Edge Channel
children.description: Nuxt 3 is landing commits, improvements, and bug fixes every day. You can opt-in to test them earlier before the next release.

children.title: <NuxtPage>
children.description: <NuxtPage> is a built-in component that comes with Nuxt. NuxtPage component is required to display top-level or nested pages located in the /pages directory.

children.title: <NuxtErrorBoundary>
children.description: Nuxt provides the <NuxtErrorBoundary> component to handle client-side errors happening in its default slot, using Vue's onErrorCaptured hook.

children.title: clearError
children.description: Nuxt provides a composable to clear all handled errors.

children.title: navigateTo
children.description: navigateTo is a router helper function that allows creating programmatic navigation for users to navigate within Nuxt application.

children.title: throwError
children.description: Nuxt provides a quick and simple way to throw errors.

children.title: useAsyncData
children.description: Within your pages, components, and plugins you can use useAsyncData to get access to data that resolves asynchronously.

children.title: useCookie
children.description: Nuxt provides an SSR-friendly composable to read and write cookies.

children.title: useError
children.description: Nuxt provides a composable to catch global errors.

children.title: useFetch
children.description: This composable provides a convenient wrapper around useAsyncData and $fetch. It automatically generates a key based on URL and fetch options, as well as infers API response type.

children.title: useRequestEvent
children.description: Nuxt provides composables and utilities for first-class server-side-rendering support.

children.title: useRequestHeaders
children.description: Nuxt provides composables and utilities for first-class server-side-rendering support.

children.title: useRoute
children.description: The useRoute composable returns the current route and must be called in a setup function, plugin, or route middleware.

children.title: useRouter
children.description: The useRouter composable returns the router instance and must be called in a setup function, plugin, or route middleware. (Within the template of a Vue component, you can access the router using $router instead.)

children.title: nuxi add
children.description: Scaffold an entity into your Nuxt application.

children.title: nuxi analyze
children.description: Analyze the production bundle or your Nuxt application.

children.title: Hello world
children.description: A minimal Nuxt 3 application only requires the app.vue and nuxt.config.js files.

children.title: Error Handling
children.description: This example shows how to handle errors in different contexts: pages, plugins, components and middleware.

children.title: Plugins
children.description: This example shows how to use the plugins/ directory to auto-register plugins.

children.title: Teleport
children.description: Vue 3 provides the <Teleport> component which allows content to be rendered elsewhere in the DOM, outside of the Vue application.

children.title: Components
children.description:
Components in the components/ directory are auto-imported and can be used directly in your templates.
You can configure other directories to support components auto-imports.

children.title: Composables
children.description:
This example shows how to use the composables/ directory to auto-import composables.
If the component file provides a default export, the name of the composable will be mapped to the name of the file. Named exports can be used as-is.

children.title: useAsyncData
children.description: This example shows how to use useAsyncData to fetch data from an API endpoint.

children.title: useCookie
children.description: This example shows how to use the useCookie API to persist small amounts of data that both client and server can use.

children.title: useFetch
children.description: This example shows how to use useFetch to fetch data from an API endpoint.

children.title: useHead
children.description: This example shows how to use useHead and Nuxt built-in components to bind meta data to the head of the page.

children.title: useState
children.description: useState is an SSR-friendly ref replacement. Its value will be preserved after server-side rendering and shared across all components using a unique key.

children.title: Layouts
children.description: This example shows how to define default and custom layouts.

children.title: Middleware
children.description: This example shows how to add route middleware with the middleware/ directory or with a plugin, and how to use them globally or per page.

children.title: <NuxtLink>
children.description: This example shows different ways to use <NuxtLink>.

children.title: Pages
children.description: This example shows how to use the pages/ directory to create application routes.

children.title: Universal Router
children.description: This example demonstrates Nuxt universal routing utilities without depending on pages/ and vue-router.

children.title: Server Routes
children.description: This example shows how to create server routes inside the server/api directory.

children.title: Config extends
children.description: This example shows how to use the extends key in nuxt.config.ts to use the base/ directory as a base Nuxt application, and use its components, composables or config and override them if necessary.

children.title: Module Extend pages
children.description: This example defines a new test page using extendPages within a module.

children.title: Reactivity Transform
children.description: This example demonstrates the support of Reactivity Transform in Nuxt 3.

children.title: Wasm
children.description: This example demonstrates the server-side support of WebAssembly in Nuxt 3.

children.title: Locale
children.description: This example shows how to define a locale composable to handle the application's locale, both server and client side.

children.title: Getting Help
children.description: At some point, you may find that there's an issue you need some help with. But don't worry! We're a friendly community of developers and we'd love to help.

children.title: Reporting Bugs
children.description: Try as we might, we will never completely eliminate bugs. One of the most valuable roles in open source is taking the time to report bugs helpfully. Even if you can't fix the underlying code, reporting a bug well can enable someone else with a bit more familiarity with the codebase to spot a pattern or make a quick fix.

children.title: Contribution
children.description: Nuxt is a community project - and so we love contributions of all kinds! ❤️

children.title: Roadmap
children.description: Nuxt is constantly evolving, with new features and modules being added all the time. This page lists the current status and schedule of our planned releases.

body.title: A beautifully designed blog system.
body.description: Build your next application with Vue 3 and experience hybrid rendering, with an improved directory structure and new features Nuxt 3 is an open source framework making web development simple and powerful.

children.title: Overview

head.title: Migrate from Nuxt 2 to Nuxt Bridge

children.description: Experience Nuxt 3 features on existing Nuxt 2 projects.

children.title: Composition API

head.title: Nuxt 2 to Nuxt Bridge: Composition API

children.description: Nuxt Bridge provides access to Composition API syntax. It is specifically designed to be aligned with Nuxt 3. Because of this, there are a few extra steps to take when enabling Nuxt Bridge, if you have been using the Composition API previously.

children.title: Overview
children.description: Nuxt 3 is a complete rewrite of Nuxt 2, and also based on a new set of underlying technologies. That means there will be significant changes when migrating a Nuxt 2 app to Nuxt 3, although you can expect migration to become more straightforward as we move toward a stable release.

children.title: Auto Imports
children.description: Nuxt 3 adopts a minimal friction approach, meaning wherever possible components and composables are auto-imported.

children.title: Meta Tags
children.description: Nuxt 3 provides several different ways to manage your meta tags.

head.title: Nuxt 2 to Nuxt 3: Plugins and Middleware
Nuxt 2 to Nuxt 3: Pages and Layouts

children.title: Runtime Config
children.description: If you wish to reference environment variables within your Nuxt 3 app, you will need to use runtime config.

children.title: Build Tooling
children.description: We use the following build tools by default:

children.title: Server
children.description: In a built Nuxt 3 application, there is no runtime Nuxt dependency. That means your site will be highly performant, and ultra-slim. But it also means you can no longer hook into runtime Nuxt server hooks.
